awd_titl_txt: Study of Convective Hazards under Anthropogenic Climate Change using innovative approaches
awd_abstract_narration:
It is difficult to assess how severe thunderstorms and tornadoes may change in a warmer climate because various factors dictate the strength and frequency of hail, severe winds, and tornadoes.  Prior efforts to determine potential changes in severe weather have been based on indirect and statistical measures of the likelihood for severe weather.  In this project, the research team will instead investigate historical severe weather events and then modify their environments to match outputs from climate model simulations.  The result of the project will be a better physical understanding of the potentials causes and frequency of these hazards.  An additional effort will use population and housing data to help estimate the impacts of severe weather hazards in a warmer climate, thereby addressing human vulnerability to these hazards.  Graduate students would be involved in the project, ensuring the professional development of the next generation of researchers.

The research team will conduct a numerical modeling study using the pseudo-global-warming (PGW) approach, wherein a variety of historical convective-weather events will be simulated both in their true 4D environment as well as in a 4D environment modified by a measure of climate change.  The research team argues that past work, including their own, on the topic has been limited to the use of environmental parameters and dynamic downscaling, both of which have significant drawbacks.  The PGW technique provides a flexible framework for experimentation and examination of cause and effect in dynamical and microphysical processes and allows for the use of higher resolutions and multiple realizations of a single case.  The project will use the WRF-ARW with input from several of the CMIP-5 and CMIP-6 models for the climate change delta.  Three hypotheses will be addressed: 1) Representative and characteristic warm- (cool-) season tornadoes will be less (more) intense under anthropogenic climate change (ACC), 2) Representative damaging straight-line wind events will be more intense, but relatively shorter-lived, under ACC, and 3) Despite decreases in vertical wind shear and increases in the height of the melting level, hailfall swath area and hailstone size at the ground will generally increase under ACC.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was motivated by the very basic question of whether hazardous convective weather in the form of tornadoes, thunderstorm-driven winds, and hailfall might be more intense in the future under anthropogenic climate change (ACC). Specifically, we sought to determine whether a given tornado, hail, or thunderstorm wind event from a past climate would be stronger (or weaker) if it instead occurred in a future climate, and if so, why.

            Toward this end, we employed an event-level “pseudo-global-warming” (PGW) approach, through which historical convective-weather events (of one or several-day duration) were simulated both in their true historical environment, as well as in five different possible future environments as projected by different  global climate models (GCMs). Projections were based on the worst-case scenario of no modification to global greenhouse gas emissions. The PGW approach inherently involves simulations run over short periods (< 48 hours), thus providing a flexible framework for experimentation and examination of cause and effect. It also allowed multiple realizations of each event at high spatial resolution.

            Our initial study sought to clarify the effects of the choices made in implementing the projections from the GCMs into the PGW simulations.  By testing a variety of methods to compute differences in the past and projected environments, it was determined that it would be advantageous to compute not only decadal averages over the month of interest, but also to compute these averages over 6-hour intervals to capture the diurnal cycle within these environments. Using 6-hour differences produced some differences in convective intensity and area of precipitation, and so was subsequently adopted for all the severe weather cases considered.

We examined the potential for increases in future tornado intensity due to ACC using an archetypal warm-season event (EF5 tornado in May 2013; WARM) and cool-season event (EF4 tornado in February 2013; COOL). As hypothesized based on meteorological arguments, the storm and associated tornado of the COOL event experienced consistent and robust increases in intensity, size, and duration in an ensemble of PGW simulations. The storm and associated tornado of the WARM event experienced increases in intensity in some of the simulations, but the response was neither consistent nor robust, and was overall weaker than in the COOL event. An assessment of the environmental characteristics of the tornadic storms provided further support of the disproportionately stronger response in the cool-season event. These results have implications on the possible strength of future tornadoes forming outside of climatologically favored seasons, in the U.S. and elsewhere around the world.

Next, we examined the potential for ACC-driven changes in future thunderstorm wind events through PGW simulations of the infamous August 2020 Midwestern U.S. derecho, the costliest thunderstorm event in U.S. history to date.  The simulations suggested that a version of this derecho event occurring near the end of the 21st century might not necessarily have more intense winds than those of the actual event, but could impact a geographical area 50 to 100% larger.  The physical chain of events that led to this greater geographical impact involved an earlier start and a more northward extension of the winds in the future derecho. Increased precipitation combined with decreased near-ground relative humidity in the future event enhanced the area of evaporative cooling and thus the cold pool, which in turn extended the area covered by the rear-inflow jet within the storm, the likely main mechanism for most of the damaging winds in the historical event.

Finally, we investigated the potential influences of ACC on hail storms near the end of the 21st century using seven historical hailstorm events over the U.S., including cool season events (COOL) and warm season events (WARM).  Despite modestly stronger updrafts in all future storms, only the COOL events showed an increase in hail sizes both within the storms and at the ground.  The WARM events produced smaller hail both within the storms and at the ground.  In addition, the hailfall area at the ground increased in COOL events and decreased in WARM events.  Increased melting depths in the WARM future environments likely contributed to the decrease in hailfall area of those storms, while expanding their areas of rainfall. 

All these results have been communicated to broad audiences by the principle investigators and their graduate students, through publications in the formal scientific literature, presentations at national and international conferences and symposia, and integration into teaching materials for courses at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign.  The three graduate students were trained in high-performance computing, numerical modeling, and process-based analyses of large datasets as they earned their degrees. This body of work has demonstrated the advantages of the PGW method for studying the effects of ACC on severe weather, and recommends future similar studies to evaluate the generality of the results found here.
